head.title: Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. - Page #25

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #25 of 71 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Mackintosh, Alexander. Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0039

div.p: Remarks & occurrences on board the Nancy Hired Transport on her return passage to Makinac or St Josephs in the month of October 1813[.]

got the square sail booms in upon deck, bent a new hawser to the kedge & let it go under foot – battened down the Hatches – braced the yards fore and aft – cleared the Boat & got the oars ready – in short made every thing as snug as possible, for on the squalls clearing away we could distinctly see the breakers astorm about a cable lenth distant – the land appearing about 2 miles […], what now must the reader think of our situation, on a lee shore riding out a most violent gale of wind in the month of October, with 2 very indifferent cables, & them of only 60 fathom each in length with a scanty stock of provisions consisting only of one Ps of pork – & ½ a quarter of mutton, 'tis true we had about 60 Wt of Biscuit but what nourishment was it for men constantly wet & wore out with fatigue! – at day light our situation was indeed a most critical one shoals in every direction to leward of us with some Islands which would have given us some shelter even we under their lee – but we dare not attempt to weigh – the wind had now abated, considerably & chopped round to WNW from WSW which made us roll gunnel in at times – we attempted to shorten in our cables but it come on to blow in squalls which obliged us to leave them – at noon the weather still continued squally with sleet & rain at 4 PM no change in either wind or weather at 5 a severe shower of hail – last part of this 24 hours, no abatement or change of wind[.]

First part of this 24 hours wind at W & blows strong with flying clouds from WNW at ½ past 9 AM a squa[ll] from the NNW which is the first change since our anchoring here, but a heavy sea running from the westward hove in some of the best bower it being the lee anchor, at noon hove up the kedge & lashed it in the larboard fore chains ready for letting go – for the first time, the weather cleared up to enable us to see to some distance, when we could perceive
